title: Wage garnishment in California. Can a judgment creditor wage garnish me if I am actually a 1099 real estate agent? Just wonderin
question: A credit card company sued and got a judgment on me. I know they like to send notice to employers to effect wage garnishments. In my situation, I am a 1099 independ contractor real estate agent working under a large broker company. If they try to wage garnish me, will that protect me from it?
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Wage garnishment,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Real estate agents,Employment as an independent contractor,Sued for debt
answers: I have represented clients that received a order to garnish their own 1099 fees, but realistically, there was no one to enforce it.

The attorneys above are current. Income, in any source, is subject to levy - whether through a wage garnishment process or other process. Pay the bill!

Disclaimer of California Attorney
Although the above response is believed to be accurate, it should not be relied upon as any type of legal advice because the information provided is incomplete. It is intended to educate the reader and a more definite answer should be based on a consultation with a lawyer. No attorney client relation is formed with me without a written contract.

Joshua P. Friedman
jfriedman@jpfassociates.com
www.losangelescollector.com

As Mr. Easlick points out, what you are owed is subject to enforcement of the judgment. While a wage garnishment may not be the proper tool for getting at your commissions, they can be taken to pay the judgment. There are just different procedures for getting to that point.

It does not matter whether you are an independent contractor or an employee. A judgment creditor may garnish any funds owed to you whether they are wages or contractual income. In the eyes of the law a rose, by any other name, is still a rose.
